Detailed Description

This package contains the logic for setting up and running the program.

It initializes PyGame, instantiates necessary global singletons, and runs the main game loop. By default, when started, Jetblade will generate a map, save the map definition file to disk (using the map seed as the filename), and then switch to gameplay mode. Notable commandline options:

  • -debug: turn on debugging output (warning: verbose!)
  • -num X: generate X maps, and exit
  • -saveimage: save an image of the entire map after generating, then exit
  • -seed X: use X as a seed for map generation
  • -mapfile X: try to load X as a map definition file, and start gameplay mode
  • -record: record every rendered frame to disk. Note: this can be toggled during gameplay as well.

Function Documentation

def jetblade.draw (   zoomLevel,
  cam,
  progress 
)

Draw the game.

def jetblade.gameLoop (  ) 

The main game loop.

Performs a target of physicsUpdatesPerSecond updates to the physics/game logic per second, and otherwise draws as many frames as possible between update cycles. For debugging purposes, you can turn on and off debugging output, and save the displayed frames to files.

def jetblade.init (  ) 

Process commandline flags and set up singletons.

def jetblade.run (  ) 

Wrapper around the introductory logic; this is where we set our cProfile hooks.

def jetblade.startGame (  ) 

Create the map(s) and player.

If we've been told to make multiple maps or to save the map, then exit once we're done.

Variable Documentation

int jetblade.physicsUpdatesPerSecond = 30

Number of physics updates to try to make each second.

Tweaking this directly determines the speed of gameplay, to the limits of the computer's hardware.

int jetblade.slowPhysicsUpdatesPerSecond = 4

Number of physics updates to try to make each second when we're recording images of the game to file.
